title: Between 1 October 2017 and 30 September 2018, will an armed group from the Philippines engage in a campaign that systematically kills 1,000 or more civilians in the Philippines?
preds:
Given the existing conditions it seems unlikely a change in position by Duterte would have any effect in the streets. August 16, 2017:
From: https://www.reuters.com/article/us-philippines-drugs/philippines-war-on-drugs-and-crime-intensifies-at-least-60-killed-in-three-days-idUSKCN1AX0BO
"Duterte said it was good that 32 criminals had been killed in Bulacan, then added: “Let’s kill another 32 every day. Maybe we can reduce what ails this country. On Thursday, he said he would not just pardon police officers who killed drug offenders during the anti-narcotics campaign, but also promote them."..."Duterte also chided human rights groups on Wednesday for getting in the way of his anti-drugs campaign and said police should shoot them if they obstructed justice, a remark the New York-based Human Rights Watch said puts activists “in grave danger”." "The exact number of people killed during the war on drugs is difficult to quantify, with no independent statistics available.....
...From the start of the drugs war to the end of July, police said over 3,400 people were killed in their operations. Police said about 2,100 deaths among some 13,500 murders over the same period were drugs-related, attributed to turf wars, informants being silenced, or vigilantes killing drug users. ....Critics maintain that members of the Philippine National Police (PNP) are executing suspects and say it is likely they have a hand in thousands of unsolved murders of drug users by mysterious vigilantes. The PNP and government reject that."
far away from the consensus on this.

President Duterte has carte blanche from his current BFF, US President LIttlefingers, to arrange for as many murders as he finds convenient.  However, he seems to have lost interest to some extent, and anyway there are several different instrumentalities available to him, so no one of them may kill enough people to meet this criterion.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.
Do we consider the Philippine Government an armed group? If so, Duterte has probably already surpassed this goal.

Obviuously duterte can be viewed differently 
It's the flipping Philippine 
Like DPRK 
No way that happens after a 10 month battle
Based on general news and GJP consensus.

@wastina You should not exclude Duterte's war on drugs. As at least during the last year the EWP determined that it was a mass killing. It's not 100% certain if they will choose to do so again, as this depends on the systematic and targeted nature of the killings related to the drug war. But so far I would assume that, as the official rethoric has not changed and drug users still get targeted systematically, this question will still be resolved positively. The consensus therefore seems a bit off to me. Do you assume that the drug war will slow down?
I'm excluding Duterte's current war on drugs
will they call it oofical army - but its a dangerous zone without questions...

@danbell7819 is perfectly correct.  There is no doubt that local police and national military and law enforcement personnel have killed more than enough people to make their quota under this Q, and will continue to do so.  This is a national campaign, conducted at the instruction or with the approval of the President of the Republic.  The fact that he uses various agencies in different parts of the country to murder people should not, in my not-very-humble opinion, mean he and minions are off the hook for the murders of thousands of civilians.   However, scoring is not necessarily connected to what the rest of us perceive as reality.  Scores on this Q will come down to the personal predilections of the GJedi.  The families of the dead people will doubtless appreciate the scrupulosity with which these distinctions will be made.  To be more nearly fair, one understands that this situation puts the scorers in a quandary owing to the definitions previously laid out.  Their proble, with which one sympathsizes, is whether to stick to the letter or the spirit of what they presumably want to know.  Stay tuned

Given the definitions and criteria above, this (in my opinion) is really either 1% or 100%. The police have killed over 2,000 civilians in the campaign against drug traffickers. Whether that is an armed group engaging in a campaign policy that knowingly results in widespread civilian deaths is something the administrators will have to clarify. Considering that the question is being asked, I assume that the answer is no given that it is not a specific civilian group being targeted, but rather an ambiguous "drug dealer" group defined by the civilian population and the police. Without clarification if the drug war (and the subsequent targeting of "drug dealers") meets the definition above, it's unlikely this will be resolved as a yes. Additionally, the lack of clarity by the government and police forces makes it difficult to assess whether its a campaign by an armed group against civilians. Therefore, I assess this as 1%, as there is no major campaign happening between armed forces that would reach this level.
